message: What was the main reason for Friedrich Merz's defeat?
How did the German parliament react to the vote?

The German parliament formally elected Friedrich Merz as chancellor in the second round of voting, after a humiliating loss in the first round that raised doubts about the stability of the next coalition government.
What impact will this have on German politics?

Merz's bid to claw back support from the AfD is seen as one of the biggest challenges facing him this term. He will engage in the battle in a weaker position than initially presumed, while Germany seeks to restore its vaunted reputation for predictability. The incoming government will have to revive the flatlining economy and fend off the far right while maintaining support for Ukraine against the backdrop of fresh uncertainty in the transatlantic relationship under Donald Trump.
Were there any unexpected outcomes from this vote?

Yes, 18 unnamed rebels from the alliance between conservatives and Social Democrats voted to deprive Friedrich Merz of the required majority in the secret ballot, which commentators called a "complete catastrophe" and "a punch to the stomach".
What were the main political alliances mentioned in the article?
The article mentions a coalition between the conservative CDU/CSU and the centre-left SPD in Germany.
Why did Friedrich Merz lose the vote?
Friedrich Merz suffered a "humiliating loss in the first round" due to "18 unnamed coalition rebels" before being elected in the second round.
What factors contributed to Merz's defeat?

Merz suffered a "humiliating loss in the first round inflicted by 18 unnamed coalition rebels" (Article_Chunk_1). He also has a "deep popularity deficit among Germans, who dislike his often brash style and mercurial temperament" (Article_Chunk_808).
How did Merz's political opponents respond?

Merz has a deep popularity deficit among Germans, who dislike his often brash style and mercurial temperament. One political opponent warned that if the teams fail to pull themselves together, “mistrust could spread in both parliamentary groups” with Merz left to doubt “before every important vote whether he actually has a majority” and “The AfD will of course try to exploit that” by sowing discord.
